author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Sore White Node On Tip Of Tongue
content: Hi, From your description, the exact location of the lesion and the type of papilla that you are referring to are not clear.In diagnosing lesions over the tongue, a clinician has to go by - the history, - the morphology of the lesion and - digital palpation(especially to look for "induration"-which may indicate a malignant lesion and in 'whitish' lesions, and also to see if the whitish 'lesion' can be easily wiped off or not).  Therefore, i will confine myself to a brief account on some of the probable lesions.  - Hypertrophied foliate papillae: located over the posterior part of the lateral borders of the tongue.These may enlarge due to infection or chronic irritation and cause concern. - Hypertrophied circumvallate papillae: These papillae, 8-12 in number, are located over the dorsum of the tongue in a 'V' shape at the junction of the oral and oropharyngeal parts of the tongue. When hypertrophied, they frequently mimic a malignant tumor. - Glossodynia: seen mostly in > 50y old women, is said to be associated with cancerophobia. Affected individuals may complain of an itching sensation over the tip and adjoining lateral borders of the tongue.The fungiform papillae are enlarged and the area appears raised and red. This condition also may be associated with a number of other diseases (iron deficiency anemias, pernicious anemia, candidiasis, diabetes mellitus, xerostomia, lichen planus etc). - minor salivary gland tumors. - malignant tumors (squamous cell carcinoma, lymphoepithelioma, lymphomas as well as others)  Although some of the lesions mentioned may not be intrinsically 'whitish' in color, they may get coated by food particles and aquire such an appearance.   In managing these lesions, generally, the threshold for biopsy is understandably low. Any such lesion, which persists beyond a reasonable period of conservative measures must be biopsied. Best wishes!

title: White spot on tongue that does not hurt
content: Hello,  I am a 21-year-old female, and I do not drink or smoke. I am in relatively good health, although I do suffer from mild asthma and acid reflux, which has not acted up since June. Along with this white spot, I also noticed small amounts of blood emerging with mucous expulsions from my nasal cavity. I was also wondering if these phenomena were related, and if you recommend professional evaluation.  Thank you for your time, UTGal

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: White spot on tongue that does not hurt
content: Hello,Apart from yeast infections which are commoner in childhood and in the immunodeficient,the likely diagnosis would be leucoplakia or oral lichen planus.Leucoplakia would be commoner at pressure spots like a denture or cheek area due to biting and with tobacco use.Lichen planus is a condition for which cause is not known produces lacy white nonpainful affecting areas of cheeks or tongue.This can be treated with with external application of steroids.If this persists do get biopsied to get a firm diagnosis.Bcarotene contaning foods like papayya,tomatoes and watermelon would be most useful for prevention.Bestwishes.

title: Cold sore or canker sore?
content: I have always had reoccurring breakouts of what I assumed were canker sores inside my mouth. I know that cold sores (caused by herpes) are generally found on the outside of the mouth, but I've read conflicting reports on whether they occur on the gums or not. I also read conflicting reports on whether canker sores appear on the gums or not. Some say they do, others say they don't.   I have had ulcers break out in my mouth everywhere from my tongue, my cheeks, the base of my gums, and the inside of my lip. They have all the appearances of a canker sore. White coating, red halo...I have never had a breakout outside of my mouth. Which is where cold sores typically break out.  I know that canker sores aren't contagious while cold sores are. Recently my boyfriend had an ulcer come out at the base of his gums. It had a white coating and looked like the ones I have gotten. But he's never had canker sores before, so now I'm worried that maybe what I've always thought are canker sores are actually cold sores...  So, to clarify my question. Can canker sores break out on the base of your gum or not? Could I possibly have cold sores?

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Green "Slime" On Top of Tongue, Can Rub Off
content: Hi, Greeish coat on the tongue may be a variant of "black hairy tongue".The tongue has a variety of papillae, some of which are called the 'filiform papillae' (mostly in the oral part of the tongue).  When these get sorrounded by mycelial threads of certain fungi such as Aspergillus Niger, a black,furry tongue results. Candida albicans also can produce a similar picture.  Chlorophyll containing chewing gums have been sited as a reason for conferring the green colour seen some cases with this condition.Antibiotic therapy is a prominent risk factor.  Best wishes!

author: Philosophy  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Sep 08, 2009 1:22 am Gender: Female
title: Diagnosed with Odontogenic Myxoma
content: Background: Female Age: 28 Never had a single cavity, filling, or any other form of work done on my teeth. Wisdom teeth have never been removed. Very good health, physically active, married 10 years. Have mild asthma, treated by rescue inhaler Non-smoker and non-drinker Do not take any medications regularly  For the past 7 years I thought a knot in my front mandible was a Mandibular Torus. It grew slowly and has been painless. However I have come to find out in recent days, after a trip to the Mayo clinic in Rochester, MN for a biopsy, that it is a rare tumor called a Odontogenic Myxoma. I have been informed that they will be doing a block excision that will also includes the removal of 6 of my front teeth. They will not be doing a bone graft as it will need to be monitored over the next 3-5 years to watch for recurrence. I will be fitted with some kind of a bridge over the missing  area of jaw bone about a month after surgery, and eligible for implants after 2 years.  These recent developments have me wondering a few things.  1) How rare is this tumor. I asked one of the 2 surgeons who will be doing my surgery this question and she was unable to say, but just stated it was very rare. That she had never seen it before. The second surgeon who has been in this field 30+ years spoke as though he had only seen it twice, and both cases the patient was quite deformed in the mouth by the time he treated them. I have tried to look up some statistics online, however the most I have been able to find is a few sites stating .07 people for every 1 million. But I am unsure how reliable these sources are.  2) When I have have a block excision of the tumor and the removal of the 6 teeth, what kind complications should I expect by not having a graft of any kind to replace the missing area of my jaw? Will I be able to talk? Are there any pictures of people who have had a block excision this large in the front mandible to give me an idea of how little or how much I should be expecting to have left of my mouth when I come out of surgery? I'm a bit concerned something this extensive being missing from my mouth for this long my frighten my children and I just want to get an idea of what I may look like afterward.  I have attached an x-ray done of the tumor a few weeks ago. I have been in for a full work up of CT scans (with and without the iodine IV), chest x-rays, blood work and biopsies. It took the pathology department 3 days longer then the surgeons expected because of the rarity of the tumor and they have determined it is benign. They have found nothing else anywhere. Nothing in my lymph nodes, and they checked my heart as I am told this tumor is usually found there instead of the mouth.  Any help, thoughts or opinions would be greatly appreciated.  Thank you...

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Diagnosed with Odontogenic Myxoma
content: Hi, Tissue that is cell-poor and  mucopolysaccharide(ground substance) -rich is said to be myxoid tissue.Tumors that have these histologic features are called myxoma.   They are uncommon (odontogenic myxomas represent  1% -17.7% of all odontogenic tumors).  Within the skeleton, they occur almost exclusively in the jaws. Outside of the jaws, they are extremely rare. Those that occur in the jaws are said to be of odontogenic origin(believed to arise from the dental papilla or follicular mesenchyme).  Odontogenic tumors pose a considerable challenge not only to the clinician (many of them resemble each other clinically), but to the histopathologist and radiologist as well.  I hope this information is useful to you.Good day!

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: impacted wisdom tooth & facial pain
content: Hello --  What's most likely to result if the nerve is damaged during a removal would be numbness. While this is probably preferable to pain, it's a close second at times. Fortunately there may be another way to approach this, and that would be to have a consult with a neurosurgeon. If the tooth is impingeing one or more branches of the facial nerve (and apparently it is) then this would be every bit as much a job for a neurosurgeon as for an oral surgeon or dentist. They could (and should) work in tandem in planning the extraction, and perhaps the  neurosurgeon could actually do the removal. That's no guarantee there wouldn't be problems, but with a neurosurgeon at least you'd have the best prediction of potential problems and, if he were to do the surgery, you'd likely also have the best chance of the best outcome. While relief of pain is ultimately necessary, avoidance of numbness or loss of range of motion is equally important.   I hope this is helpful. Please follow up with us here as needed. Good luck to you.

content: Hi,  I've been dealing with recurring cold sores, one after the other since August of 08'.  They appear on different parts of my lips.  They look like the regular cold sores I usually get. My doctor thinks that there is nothing more I can do, and that I should take lots of vitamin C and lysine.  He thinks its common that colds sores reoccur in the winter.  But how can that be in my case when this started in the late summer?  What I didn't tell my doctor is that I think its something more then just recurring  cold sores.  This may be far-fetched, but about a year and sometime earlier, I was with a man whom I had oral sex with.  The first time I performed oral sex on him, I woke up with a cold sore.  It went away and I thought nothing of it.  Later on I got two yeast infections and a sore throat that had white puss and looked inflamed.  I went to the doctor to get it looked at.  I told the doctor the story, and she thought it could just be Mono.  The test went through, and I tested negative for Mono and  any STD of the throat.    Since then I've been single, not dealing with anyone, and out of no where this coldsore thing happens.  I really worried, and these coldsore are taking over my life. author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Recurring Cold Sores: Every two to three weeks.
content: Hello --  It is the nature of cold sores, usually caused by herpes simplex virus, to be somewhat erratic, random and unpredictable, except the reasonable certainty that at some time they will show up again. There are also often periods when they are especially active, but they are usually aggravated most, to my understanding of the subject, during the summer, due to exposure to sunlight. Continue to use the Zovirax, which is excellent for suppressing this until outbreaks die down. There really is little else that can be done other than the vitamin C, which does seem to help.  Your theory about oral sex may not be so far fetched, it just may not make a lot of difference. While you may now have herpes simplex type II acting in concert with the original virus, the two are so similar as to make little difference, and either can be transposed to the "other end" depending upon sexual habits, etc. There's really little to differentiate between the two and the treatment is exactly the same.  I hope this is of some help to you. Good luck with this and please, by all means, be up front in any future relationships, as your partner will certainly either thank you for your honesty or, if of questionable character, may just walk away from the possibility of infection. I suppose that comment is judgemental, but if the relationship is an honest and solid one, something like this really shouldn't get in the way. On  the other hand, if more casual sex is in play, you certainly still owe your partner the heads-up.   Best of luck to you with this. Hopefully the current flareup will soon resolve and give you some peace for a while.

The blister pops then looks like it's going to heal and turns back into a blister again. posted_time: Post  by imagine72 » Wed Jan 28, 2009 2:34 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: canker sore turned into blister
content: Hello --  Some recurrent canker sores can cycle numerous times, depending upon what the trigger may be. If this one is in a single spot and keeps recycling itself, it may be getting irritated by something like a rough edge of a tooth or ingestion of something that aggravates canker sores, like citrus or other acidic fruits or juices, figs, and they also can be caused or aggravated by certain conditions like low levels of vitamin B-12. If it doesn't resolve on its own pretty soon you might want to try GlyOxide, if you haven't already. It's available over the counter and is a combo of peroxide and glycerine, so it stays put where it's placed with a dropper (unlike plain peroxide, which only serves as a momentary mouthwash). If that doesn't clear this one up, or if you start to have more recurrent ones, you may have advanced to a more complex form of the original problem. It's benign, but obviously can be very painful.   I hope this  is helpful. Good luck to you. Follow up with us here as needed.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Infection or nerve exposed
content: Hi there -  Generally an abcess will cause marked local swelling and local fever in addition to pain. Early on there may just be pressure on some part of the nerve, which can cause excruciating pain without having gotten that much worse. Although an infected tooth could once upon a time cause systemic infection and mitral valve prolapse (MVP) used to be a concern and cause for premedication, it's now not considered to be a major concern. Add to that the fact that you're already on antibiotics and things should be fully managed for now, except, of course, for the  pain. The pain is a direct result of pressure on the nerve of the  tooth,  which can sometimes  simply be nothing more than air pressure. Those nerves are very, very sensitive when exposed or touched by anything. You're covered by the antibiotics you're taking and needn't be concerned about endocarditis right now. Getting the tooth repaired or removed will  resolve the primary problem, which right now is pain.   I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you and please update us after you've seen the dentist.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Osteomyelitis of the Jaw?
content: Hello -  This doesn't sound like osteomyelitis, but rather perhaps an abcessed tooth which has created a fistula (or even just infectious tooth abcess material having drained into one of the parotid glands via fistula, and which has now maybe created a secondary pocket). Amoxycillin is a reasonable first-line antibiotic for this, but probably something stronger, like ciprofloxacin, may become necessary, as well as possible intervention by an oral surgeon to clear  up any residual problems, may be necessary. In fact, that's where I'd go next, and see an oral surgeon, who might be have better insight into this sort of thing.  Hope this is helpful. Please follow up with us as necessary and also update us as to progress.

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: parotid gland
content: Hello,  The parotid gland is the same glands that swell when you get the mumps. They are the 2 largest of our salivary glands and they empty into our mouth. Being that the Doctor actually saw the swollen gland, I wouldn’t want to downplay his diagnosis. If it turns out not to be a pimple, another thought would be that you could have a viral or bacterial infection in the parotid gland called parotitis, you may have a salivary duct stone/stones or it can be infected from poor oral hygiene. Being that it is a salivary gland, sour will increase the pain, so will pinching it. Treatment consists of antibiotics, warm compresses, massaging the gland and try to express the content through the duct into your mouth and if it doesn’t get any better, your doctor may have to drain it surgically.

title: Re: Hard Invisable Bump on Inside Lower Lip
content: Hello -  It  sounds like you're describing apthous stomatitis (common caker sore), and sometimes these, as they heal, can leave a firm, painless bump, especially if accidentally bitten repeatedly while chewing or if nibbled on habitually by the "owner" as it is healing. title: very small clear blisters on my lips
content: well ok here's my story, last year i had to be tested got herpes because i had this serious out of nowhere outbreak. i had ulcerations on my tongue and on my lips which got infected. the doctor i saw had just simply stated i had genital herpes, i kinda didn't argue because it had gone through my head also. so i was prescribed viral medication along with a bacterial because it was infected. i got tested a few days later and the test apparently came back negative with no acute signs of herpes. so my question is what was that? ever since then i have been getting these very very little small clear blisters that are firm, they sometimes itch and if i do scratch them they flare up for a few mins and then they go back down and you don't notice them again. it frightens me because i wanna know what they are! if anyone has any idea please help!
posted_time: Post  by californiagal1990 » Tue Nov 11, 2008 9:51 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: very small clear blisters on my lips
content: Hi there -  It sounds like you do have herpes which first blossomed as oral stomatitis, responded to the initial treatment, then returned a false negative test result, probably because you'd just been treated for it. While it should show up anyway,  sometimes immediately after (or during) treatment the virus will go dormant and not show up.   Your current symptoms still sound like herpes. I can't prove this at a distance, of course, but the description of the original outbreak and the subsequent symptoms, plus the fact that you say the possibility had crossed your mind early on, suggests you had placed yourself at risk of infection, so having it show up isn't surprising. A follow-up test would be useful, and it doesn't matter whether it's genital herpes or just a flareup from an early case of chickenpox; it is treated the same, and is essentially the same thing. It's uncomfortable and can be communicated to others, so it should be treated and, more importantly, should be accurately and definitively diagnosed. I'd either go back to the original doctor or a different one, and be re-tested, then do whatever it takes to get the symptoms  under control and watch out for future flareups, which can be fairly infequent or can be somewhat regular, depening upon the individual.   I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you. Follow up with us as needed.

I have been taking amoxicillin antibiotics for almost 10 days now, and to no avail.  Within the last two weeks my jaw and mouth have been: -popping and cracking all over the place, both sides -getting REALLY bad toothaches, mostly on the left side, mostly upper teeth -getting pain pressure or plugged feeling in ears, mostly left side -limited movement with jaw -when i smile or open mouth wide i get pain in temple, ear, and pulling pain in the spot where i had been getting my headaches -its hard to eat, yawn, etc. -i feel dizzy or like my eyes are being affected somehow  The pain has gotten really bad and has been progressing really quickly to the point where i am in tears frequently and the pain is moderate in the morning but by the early evening is severe. author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Is it normal to have some whiteness on the tongue?
content: Hello, This is a common condition and it can be aggravated by smoking.  It is not necessarily thrush but often is just accumulated dead skin cells, bacteria and debris.  Brushing is advised as well as quitting smoking, avoiding dehydration by drinking plenty of water and increasing fiber in your diet. Crunchy foods — such as apples, broccoli and popcorn — help scrape debris from your tongue.  It is usually temporary and harmless.  I hope this helps.

title: Small bump on right side of jaw.
content: Hello,  About a month ago I had oral surgery to extract a wisdom tooth on the right side of my mouth.  Since then, the extraction sight has healed nicely, but I've noticed a small bump present in my jaw close to where the tooth used to be.  Now, usually I would not be concerned and would assume that it is simply a side effect of the surgery.  However, my wife was diagnosed with HPV about a year ago, which means that I've certainly contacted it as well.  My wife and I engaged in oral sex frequently and I have recently become aware that HPV can cause oral cancer in individuals who practice oral sex.  Should I be concerned that this lump is more than a side effect of the oral surgery or am I just freaking myself out over nothing?  Are there any other symptoms or signs that would let me know one way or the other?    I've scheduled an appointment with my dentist soon and plan to ask her about it.  Is there any specific questions I should ask her?
posted_time: Post  by gib » Wed Oct 29, 2008 4:51 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: Re: Small bump on right side of jaw.
content: Hello,  This is more likely to be an enlarged lymph node as it occurs in a lymph node region (submental). Following throat, gum, or dental infections or inflammation, the draining lymph nodes become enlarged, painful and tender.   After control of infection or inflammation with adequate course of antibiotics, they should regress in size but never to normal size. These enlarged nodes are usually soft to firm, not painful, mobile and less than 1 cm.  Since it occurred after tooth extraction, the possibility that it is reactionary to inflammation in this area is high, however, direct clinical examination and a thorough history is the best way for identification of its possible causes.  If your physician would see it of benign origin he may recommend serial examination, as nodes who become smaller or stationary are reassuring while those increasing in size or number are concerning and are investigated promptly.   It is true that there is an increase in the risk of oral cancers in those who practice oral sex, but mainly in those exposed to multiple partners (more than 5), however, there is no approved test to find HPV in men. To my knowledge, this subject is still an area of research.  I would advise you to follow up with your doctor.  Please keep us updated.  Best regards.

author: XComsGirl  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Sep 21, 2008 4:02 am Gender: Female
title: Consistent Bump on Inside Lower Lip
content: Hi.   About two months ago I noticed a bump on the inside of my lower lip. Thinking it was a cold sore, I left it alone.   It started to grow and shrink in size, however, and has not gone away. It is obviously not a cold sore, but it does not seem like a mucous cyst either (since the descriptions I've seen of those are clear/blueish bumps). Mine looks very much like a pimple (red sides with tiny white bump in the middle).   Also, a large, whiteish bump often grows from the main bump which makes eating and drinking difficult since I keep biting it and rubbing food against it accidentally. I started putting hydrogen peroxide on it a few weeks ago, once or twice a day, and that seems to help with the white growth. However, it never makes the original bump go away. At times, when it grows larger, it looks like a blister (with the white bump in the middle of a clearer seal), so perhaps it is a mucous cyst.   I don't even know which kind of doctor to go to for this, and I don't want to go to a regular doctor just to be told I'll have to go to a different one. Also, from what I've read about mucous cysts, they have to be surgically removed. I really don't want to have that. If this thing in my mouth is annoying but not harmful, that really doesn't seem necessary. If it is a cyst, is there any way of getting rid of it without surgery?
posted_time: Post  by XComsGirl » Sun Sep 21, 2008 4:17 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Consistent Bump on Inside Lower Lip
content: Hello -  What you describe sounds like oral stomatitis, a canker sore which sometimes forms spontaneously and, with luck, will resolve within a week or two. However, sometimes these things, which are actually usually caused by a virus, can be re-aggravated so often by being in the wrong spot and getting bitten, that they develop a bacterial superinfection (meaning superimposed, not a super bug). This is why stubborn ones tend to respond to hydrogen peroxide, and I'd continue using that as often as practical. Also, if you can find it, there's a product  called Gly-Oxide, which is peroxide in a glycerine suspension, which makes it thicker so that it stays put and is able to work longer on the actual spot. You might ask a pharmacist if this is still available. It's a lot easier to use than pure peroxide.   If the lesion doesn't resolve soon, you may need to have a doctor look at it -- most general practitioners should be able to deal with this -- and either be started on a special anti-viral medication or perhaps have the lesion cauterized. It should be looked at if it stays much longer, as it could cause a scar (with a permanent bump at the site) which could attract yet more biting, additional lesions, etc.  I hope this is helpful. Please follow up with us as needed.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: small white lump on back of mouth
content: Hi there -  What you describe could be a cyst or enlarged lymph node, or possibly a canker sore that hasn't fully develped yet. These latter are usually painful, but since it isn't open as yet, it may not have fully developed. Then again, it could be something that's been there all along and you've just recently noticed, an anatomical anomaly that isn't important. So long as it's not causing symptoms I wouldn't be too concerned, but you should have it looked at regardless. It doesn't sound as though it's anything urgent, and if it does become painful and red then it's probably a canker sore (stomatitis). These tend to run their course and go away.   Nonetheless, if this thing doesn't disappear within a week, or if it becomes larger, painful, etc., then it should be looked at by a doctor.  Hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Dry Socket and the Contraceptive Pill
content: Hello, I have never heard this side effect associated with oral contraceptives.  Your best shot at avoiding dry socket is to follow your doctors orders exactly, do not suck out of a straw, rest until you recover and try not to do anything that might dislodge the clot that forms following extraction.  In some cases it just cannot be avoided as the cause is something you can't control.  It can be related to a difficult extraction, a fragment of tooth or root left there, or even some bacterial infection at the site.  Some people develop this in spite of everything going "right" otherwise.  Best wishes and good luck with the coming procedure.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Pain in upper rear tooth
content: Hi Pjcard,  Tooth pain can be caused by several things.  Sensitive teeth can cause the pain as can a dental abscess.  Pain coming from the tooth is often worse when pressing on the tooth.  Tooth pain may also be referred from another place, most commonly the ear or the sinuses.  It may be that you are actually having some inflammation of the middle/inner ear or the maxillary sinus (located in the cheek bone).    If this pain continues I'd recommend you see your doctor for an evaluation.  An Ear/Nose/Throat specialist may also be of help.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello, There seems to be a genetic tendency to get these sores since some people are much more prone than others.  There is no known cure or definite cause of these mouth ulcers which can be very painful.    The usual preventive measures that may help reduce the incidence include being careful about eating any foods that may traumatize your mouth such as sharp-edged chips, high acid foods, nuts, and some spices.  Keep a food diary so you can discover if there is any food-link to your outbreaks.  Secondly, don't talk and chew at once - more likely to bite your mouth if you do this and the result can be a sore.  Use good dental hygiene and a soft toothbrush.  This can help get rid of offending foods that might linger in the mouth.    My son actually noticed that his occur when he doesn't eat enough vegetables.  He has never liked veggies but once he began eating them regularly (his Japanese wife is a good cook and uses lots of vegetables) he noticed the cankers didn't happen.  When his wife traveled back to Japan to visit her family, he slipped back into his bad American diet and the cankers started again.  Now, he eats the greens daily whether he wants to or not.  Just an interesting case that was easy enough for him to prevent the sores once he discovered what worked for him.  Once you have a sore, try not to irritate it by rubbing your tongue on it.  Healing will occur faster if it is not irritated further so eat soft foods and try to leave it alone.  There are some topical treatments that can reduce the pain and possibly speed the healing.  Some are by prescription and a doctor or dentist can recommend; others are available over the counter such as anesthetic solutions or ointments (numbing qualities in mouth products similar to what is used for teething babies.  Good luck.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Sat Nov 17, 2007 11:41 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Wisdom teeth can cause distress, that's for sure.  Some people are able to have them come in without difficulty but for most it's crowded in there.    They can come in one at a time or all at once - totally individual.  Also, some people have genetically absent wisdom teeth (one or more) so it is possible that there could be less than four total.  Your dental xrays should be able to determine this.  Wisdom teeth can also erupt partially, stay completely impacted, or erupt fully - in short time or over a long time.  Again, it's all up to the individual, how much room is in the mouth, etc.  Your pain could well be coming from this tooth but I can't determine that for sure.  If your sore throat and headache continue you should have it checked out.  You could be experiencing some type of seasonal allergy that is causing a little drainage, making your throat sore, but I would think the doctor would be able to visualize redness if this were the case.    Take pain relievers such as acetaminophen to get you by until your dental appointment but if that doesn't do the trick or you have other symptoms of infection such as fever, swelling, etc. you should call the office to see if they can work you in sooner for a non-routine exam.  Good luck with this.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Sj,  TMJ is a condition where the joint at the top of the jaw (near the ear) becomes inflamed.  It sounds like this is probably what is going on in your case.  There are several different reasons this inflammation can occur.  Treatment depends on the cause.  I would recommend you see an Ear, Nose, and Throat specialist for further evaluation and treatment recommendations.  Your dentist may also be able to evaluate this and make sure it isn't related to your wisdom teeth.  Best wishes.

author: Matt Foertsch  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Mon Aug 20, 2007 1:43 am
title: BB shot in Mouth 7years ago. Pain in that area?
content: Hello, I'm a healthy 23 year old Male. When I was about 16 I accidently shot myself in the mouth with a BB gun. I didn't think it was loaded and I stuck it in my mouth and pulled the trigger. The BB lodged in the fleshy sort of area on the upper left side of mouth, not quite at the jaw or the throat thank god. Anyways I didn't tell my parents or anybody about it because I was scared. Dumb, I know. So a few years went by and it never really bothered me or anything and then when I was about 18 or 19 it started to worry me because I thought maybe it could travel through my body or hurt me in some way. I went to the dentist who took X-rays and found the BB still in the place where I fired it. He suggested I see an oral surgeon to have it removed. I saw the oral surgeon and he said since it had been so long that anything bad would have already happened and there was no need to take it out because the body forms some kind of shell around it and it will just stay where it is. All of the sudden two days ago I started getting pretty bad pain, especially when I chew, right around that area and I'm really scared it's related to the BB. Could it, this many years later, be doing harm? Can it travel to my heart or brain? If it was a copper BB can it poison me some how?  I would greatly appreciate any advice. I am going to make an appointment with my dentist tomorrow and have an X-ray done as soon as possible to make sure it hasn't moved anywhere over the last few years. And if the pain doesn't go away I might go to the hospital in the next few days because it really does hurt. thanks
posted_time: Post  by Matt Foertsch » Mon Aug 20, 2007 2:07 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Matt Foertsch,  I agree with your oral surgeon that after this long it is unlikely to cause you any problems such as eroding deeper into the bone/brain or getting into a blood vessel and traveling elsewhere.  It does occasionally happen where a foreign body begins causing pain after many years, sometimes related to recent trauma in the area (even mild).  Seeing a dentist or oral surgeon about this is appropriate to make sure it is OK.  If it is not causing you any problems I agree with the surgeon that it probably does not need to come out.  If it beginning to cause pain it should probably be removed.  Regarding the copper issue, cases have been described where a person has developed lead poisoning from an embedded bullet that was leeching out the lead from within it.  This is an unusual occurrence and I am not aware of such reports with BB's; however, I cannot guarantee that this won't happen.    Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi TMalonson,  My knowledge of dental issues is not sufficient enough to be able to comment on having your teeth removed.  However, I am very suspicious that you may have a deep seated infection in the bone since multiple courses of antibiotics are not clearing it.  I would suggest you see an oral-maxillary surgeon for further evaluation.  Specifically, you may want to ask to be evaluated for osteomyelitis (the bone infection).  If osteomyelitis is present it takes long term antibiotics to clear and may need surgical debridement to fully heal.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Salivary glands can become blocked for several reasons, most commonly due to a small stone that forms (usually from calcium or some other substance solidifying) in the gland that subsequently becomes lodged in the duct.  If you aren't experiencing pain they usually are not harmful and will resolve eventually.  Eating things that make you salivate (such as sour foods, etc) can help wash out the stone and resolve the problem.  It shouldn't stop your trip but if it hasn't resolved by the time you get back it's probably a good idea to have it evaluated by the oral surgeon.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Mon Aug 27, 2007 11:33 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Tongue disturbance
content: Dear Elliemay,  i think that this could be part of the normal degeneration and regeneration of the tongue but a little bit too fast.   On the other hand, it could be abnormal. i recommend that you pay a visit to your doctor to take a look at it when it is at its peak. author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi HARTunderATTACKxx, Piercings done without a sterile procedure are even more susceptible to infection. The appearance of blue may be a  result of bruising and the redness may be either irritation or infection. I am quite sure that even though you are attempting to "hide" this from your parents they probably already at least suspect that you have done this just by the appearance on your lip. I would suggest that you remove the piercing and if you like it as much as you say you do, talk it over with your parents and if they are agreeable have it done by a professional. Keep in mind that if they adamantly refuse you doing so they are only trying to do what is best for you. Now, my concern for you is that you stated that you are bulimic. Eating disorders (Bulimia) are very dangerous. Do you realize the consequences of having this disorder? Medical conditions that may result from this condition include erosion of tooth enamel, electrolyte imbalances, (which if are severe enough may cause death), irregular heart rhythms, (severe cases may result in heart attack and possible death), rupture of the esophagus or stomach, etc. etc. I would strongly suggest that you seek treatment for this disorder. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Dear agentyandu, Here at The Doctors Lounge, we do not recommend lip piercing. Lip piercing may be associated with several hazards. If you have a bleeding tendency disease that has not been diagnosed yet then you risk bleeding to a dangerous degree. There is always the possibilty of infection at the site of trauma. More dangerously, there is a risk of a slow infection that slowly enters the blood stream and silently causes damage of the heart valves and could later lead to stroke. There are cases 'bacterial endocarditis' that have been recorded after lip piercing.

author: stephanie0107  Guest Posts: 12 Joined: Sun Jun 26, 2005 1:18 am Location: United States  Contact:   Contact stephanie0107       AOL
title: Mouth ulcer
content: Hello Friend, I hope by now that your symptoms have improved. Due to the fact that it was initiated by trauma, you can pretty much rule out oral cancer. Cold sores (also may be referred to as canker sores or herpes simplex virus of the oral mucosa) should heal within 3-4 wks maximum. If not completely healed within this time frame, you will need to see your physician and have a biopsy (removal of small sample of tissue for analysis). Based on your history, most likely you have a simple mouth ulcer, which can be a  very painful white or yellow open sore that occurs anywhere on the mucous membrane of your mouth. If it developes into a cyst or unbearable swelling, go to your physician. In the meantime, decrease smoking and alcohol intake, maintain oral hygiene as tolerated and Ibuprofen may help to alleviate swelling which will in turn decrease some of the discomfort. Be sure to avoid spicy foods and lean toward bland foods and neutral liquids (water, Gatorade, or 7-Up as tolerated). Also, consider over the counter lidocaine  if available to you or something to that effect (ask the pharmacist or your dentist) if pain is unbearble.  Much luck. LMK how you are doing.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi sylvia_c, Apparently sinus disorders and any sort of brain lesion have been ruled out as causative factors, and this symptom is not generally a side effect of synthroid. The sense of smell and taste are very closely related and dysfunctions may have many causes, from recent infections, dehydration, smoking, vitamin deficiencies (B12 specifically), mineral deficiencies, etc. Have you had a recent dental exam to rule out any disorders? author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi mitch1973, In my opinion the heating in your home and your symptoms may be a coincidence, especially since they are persisting even though you are not using your heat. My first thought when there is a complaint of unquenchable or unusual  thirst is symptoms of diabetes. Some of the symptoms of diabetes are: unusual thirst, excessive hunger,frequent urination, unusual weight loss, extreme fatigue or lack of energy, blurred vision, frequent or recurring infections,cuts and bruises that are slow to heal, tingling &/or numbness in hands &/or feet etc. I would strongly suggest an evaluation to rule this out, as well as any other anomolies. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: What you are experiencing is an abnormal sensation in the tongue. Most of the authorities associate taste and smell together all the time so what you might think is related to taste could actually be related to smell.   Taste and smell dysfunctions have several causes  1. Common cold and influenza.  2. Nose and throat infections.  3. Dry mouth.  4. Smoking (especially pipe). Do you smoke?  5. Vitamin B-12 or mineral (like zinc) deficiency.  6. Gingivitis. 7. Drug side effects such as antithyroid drugs, captopril, griseofulvin, lithium, penicillamine, procarbazine, rifampin, vinblastine, or vincristine.  8. Sjogren's syndrome (Dry mouth and eyes associated with some autoimmune diseases).  9. Bell's palsy (Paralysis of the nerve going to the face causing facial droop). Does not sound like it in your case.  10. Here's one more really unlikely possibility: Since sensation ultimately resides in the brain, the problem could be upstairs. Migraine, epilepsy and brain tumor all come to mind, but each of these would be exceptionally rare explanations for your problem.  I would advise you to see your doctor and have an examination of the nerves of your face, nose, ears, throat and tongue if your symptoms persist or worsen, or if your symptoms appear to be associated with other unusual symptoms.

content: Dear ichip, Oral ulcers are common and occur at times of stress when the body's immunity decreases. Given your history of depression it could well be the cause. author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Saliva is the natural mouthwash we were born with. People who do not have sufficient flow of saliva tend to suffer from more dental caries and periodontal disease. They have more trouble wearing dentures.   Bad breath is worst when there is little or no saliva flow, for example after a night's sleep. As soon as one wakes up and starts to salivate, the smell recedes somewhat.   Another classic way to get saliva flowing is to drop a few drops of lemon on your tongue (also helpful for saxophone players).   It becomes obvious then that saliva should smell a little offensive as it is responsible for ridding the mouth of its bad odours.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Chameleon, Sores on the tongue could arise from many causes ranging from a bacterial infection to cancer. The presence of bumps on either side of the tongue as opposed to only one side is against cancer (cancer usually develops as a painless bump on one side of the tongue). Other possible causes: oral herpes simplex infection, canker sores, tuberculosis, bacterial infections, or early-stage syphilis. It could also be an immune system problem or an allergy. The cause can usually be determined within the context of careful history taking and examination. Please keep these causes in mind during your next visit to the doctor and try to raise these possibilities for him/her.  Good luck.

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  Herpetic infections of the lips are quite common and could be transmitted to others as well as re-infect self by autoinoculation (eg. touching the lip sore and then wiping the eyes). As you rightly pointed out, canker sores are not found on the lips/gums/palate.  Topical (to apply over the lesion) antiviral medications may reduce viral shedding and increase patient comfort. For recurrent sores, that might not be enough, and emollients may be tried. If the recurrence is more than 6 time a year, oral antiviral medications may be tried so as to prevent it from happening. Immunodeficiency is another reason oral antiviral meds may be begun.  Hope this helps.  Warm regards,  Bill
